qas.question: What natural process formed the land masses that would become the Samoan islands?
Which of the Samoan islands has active volcanoes?
What's the name of the highest peak in Samoa?
What volcano created the Saleaula lava fields?
What is the source of solidified lava on Mata o le Afi?
What is different about Mauga Afi compared to the other islands?
What is the highest point in Mauga Afi?
When was a mantle plume discovered near Magua Alfi?
What is Mata o le Afi probably the result of?

context: The Samoan islands have been produced by <a0_0>vulcanism<a0_0/>, the source of which is <b5_0>the Samoa hotspot<b5_0/> which is probably the result of <b9_0>a mantle plume<b9_0/>. While all of the islands have volcanic origins, only <a1_0>Savai'i<a1_0/>, the western most island in Samoa, <b6_0>is volcanically active<b6_0/> with the most recent eruptions in Mt Matavanu (1905–1911), Mata o le Afi (1902) and Mauga Afi (<b8_0>1725<b8_0/>). The highest point in Samoa is <a2_0><b7_0>Mt Silisili,<a2_0/> at <a3_0>1858<a3_0/> m (6,096 ft)<b7_0/>. The Saleaula lava fields situated on the central north coast of Savai'i are the result of the <a4_0>Mt Matavanu<a4_0/> eruptions which left 50 km² (20 sq mi) of solidified lava.
